title: Entextualization and the Improvised Past
abstract: Drawing on recent developments in improvisation studies, the author argues that the reconstruction of improvisatory practices in eighteenth- and early nineteenth-century European music entails the cultivation of archaeological (as well as historical) modes of inquiry and digital (as well as literary) sensibilities. The anthropological concept of entextualization is deployed to illustrate how aspects of improvisation that defy literal forms of representation might be accessed through material culture, algorithmic processes, embodied reenactment, and simulation.

FN1.text: 1. For overviews of these developments, see George E. Lewis’s ( 2013 ) response and Paul Steinbeck’s ( 2013 ) paper from this panel.

FN2.text: 2. In his preface, Czerny describes Miss Cecilia as “a talented and well-educated girl of about twelve years old” ( 1837–41 , iv).

FN3.text: 3. On the early modern development of rule-based technical literature (of which Johann Joseph Fux’s Gradus ad Parnassum is a striking musical example), see Luhmann 2000 , 198–99; see also Julie E. Cumming’s ( 2013 ) paper from this panel.

FN4.text: 4. For a detailed consideration of Leibniz’s combinatorial philosophy and its impact on eighteenth-century musical thought, see Eckert 2000 , 55–100; see also Klotz 2006 on Leibniz (99–112), Riepel (223–44), and Kirnberger (245–62).

FN5.text: 5. “Archaeology” is invoked here not only to bring its Foucauldian epistemological connotations into play, but also to register the ways it has recently informed studies of performance and media: see, for instance, Giannachi, Kaye, and Shanks 2012 and Huhtamo and Parikka 2011 .

FN6.text: 6. On reenactment as historical mode and historiographical symptom, see McCalman and Pickering 2010 .

FN7.text: 7. “Musica est exercitium arithmeticae occultum nescientis se numerare animi.” Letter to Christian Goldbach, April 17, 1712, in Leibniz 1734–42 , 1: 241.

FN8.text: 8. In this sense, I both echo and respond to Emily I. Dolan’s ( 2011 ) recent call to arms.
